text.tspan: The acts of the mind, wherein it exerts its
power over simple ideas, are chiefly these
three: 1. Combining several simple ideas into
one compound one, and thus all complex ideas are
made. 2. The second is bringing two ideas,
whether simple or complex, together, and setting
them by one another so as to take a view of them
at once, without uniting them into one, by which
it gets all its ideas of relations. 3. The third
is separating them from all other ideas that
accompany them in their real existence: this is
called abstraction, and thus all its general
